turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: hey :) Today I\'m representing an organization called "Save the Children", an international group that aims to provide aid to children

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Save them from what?

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: from poverty and from disaster mostly. If you choose to donate money, it goes to providing food to impoverished children

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: I can think of a lot more worthwhile charities.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: That may be true, but Save the Children has been recognized as reliable by charity rater. Additionally, this one has a high percentage of money raised going directly to helping support the cause. hundreds of thousands of children are dying every week due to lack of food

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: There are three kinds of charities I never donate to:   children, diseases and veterans

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Maybe this could be an exception for you then? I can understand your reasoning, but famine is a huge problem especially right now. More crop harvests are failing reducing the already low amount of food to near-nothing

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Maybe thats nature limiting overpopulation.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: True, although higher populations in famine-ridden countries are necessary. There needs to be more people that are able to farm. Additionally, it's good karma. Every cent helps

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: my cents go to worthwhile charities not the ones in those three categories.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: That's understandable. What would you consider a worthwhile charity?

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Homeless shelters, food pantries, environmental stuff....

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Food pantries? A lot of food worldwide comes from countries such as Zimbabwe or Haiti (countries that work with Save the Children). Right now there's famine, but by donating it will ultimately increase the worldwide food, and reduce the need for food pantries as a whole. Even though it's marketed at children, it's moreso helping the areas that have a high child poverty rate

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: There are too many children.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: Makes sense, but countries like Italy or Japan are experiencing a population shift. Even in countries like USA and France, more doctors and scientists are retiring than graduating. So we need kids to supplement all of those areas

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: There are probably less doctors because the education is expensive not because there aren't enought children

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: In France tuition is not as expensive as in USA. There is a lack of population from 18-24, and there's even less of a population below 15. In Japan, the birthrate is low so keeping children is key as the population retires more. Children are the future work force, and help countries run economically and socially. By supporting this charity you would directly be supporting your future

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: It sounds like nature is taking care of overpopulation.  I applaud that.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: A lot of the time it isn't necesarrily overpopulation. In the case of Syria, there's a widespread civil war. Within the first quarter of 2018, over 1000 children were murdered by both sides. Save the Children has a mission to get as many children out of there as possible, because their heads are being used as trophies. It's sick and financial donation is the best way to help besides going there yourself

turns.speaker: speaker2
turns.text: Maybe the war is taking care of overpopulation.  Perhaps I should rethink my opinion on war.

turns.speaker: speaker1
turns.text: That's understandable. So you're not interested in donation at all? To help keep children save from harm
